abstract.p: Grace Glueck reviews work of Danish painter Nina Sten-Knudsen at DCA Gallery (S)

block.p: Turner, Claude Lorrain, painters of the Hudson River School and other masters of 17th- to 19th-century landscape are brought into these gigantic canvases by the Danish painter Nina Sten-Knudsen, with the aim of joining then with now. Ms. Sten-Knudsen does not so much paint the romantic landscape as she paints about it, revisiting in post-past fashion questions of space, perspective, figuration and other approaches taken for granted in pre-20th-century work.

Turner, Claude Lorrain, painters of the Hudson River School and other masters of 17th- to 19th-century landscape are brought into these gigantic canvases by the Danish painter Nina Sten-Knudsen, with the aim of joining then with now. Ms. Sten-Knudsen does not so much paint the romantic landscape as she paints about it, revisiting in post-past fashion questions of space, perspective, figuration and other approaches taken for granted in pre-20th-century work.

Her scenes, complicated by layers of allusion and multiple focuses not governed by perspective, can't be read in conventional landscape terms. In the show's title painting, ''Landscape, Later,'' for instance, a vast Turneresque terrain of theatrical intensity opens up, with hazy distant peaks and a romantic sunset. But a heavy cloud bank of unrelieved black suggests the monochrome space of modern paintings.

More in the Hudson River School line, trees, tiny figures and a rustic cabin appear at various distances, while close up there are two ancestral images from 19th-century photographs and, at right, a realistic vignette of a figure bent over what could be a typewriter. As a questioning of traditional landscape, this medley doesn't really work, but its scale and ambition makes it interesting.

In ''Sigma,'' a network of twinkling city lights is superimposed on a dark background of painted and photographed monumental ruins from the past combined with painted and photographed fragments of present-day structures and advertising signs. A panel flush next to it is a pure monochrome gray rectangle meant, I take it, to convey contemporary concerns and also to cool down the busyness of the adjacent scene. But the whole comes off as more of a stage backdrop than a painting in depth.
Still, although their execution leaves something to be desired, the ideas of landscape as theater in this show are worth examining.
